title: Did Paul McCartney or John Lennon write the most Beatles songs? - Quora

response.answer_text: Aside from their co-written songs, John wrote a few more songs than Paul. Paul wrote their first single that got them their 1st taste of success, and Paul also wrote the majority of their hit singles. Paul also wrote a dozen or so songs for other artists that were successful. Paul is in the Guinness book of records as the most popular songwriter of all time  After the Breakup of the Beatles, Paul wrote more hits and songs than Lennon until Lennon was no longer with us. Both were inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in the 90’s followed by George and Ringo. McCartney is credited as the writer on 32 number one hits in the US to Lennons 26 (with 23 co-written), whereas Lennon authored 29 UK number ones to McCartney's 28 (25 co-written). Most No.1 albums on US chart - group The Beatles – John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr – have more No.1 albums in the US (19) and UK (15) than anyone else. The band’s US tally includes nine consecutive No.1s from 1965–68 and chart-topping debuts for all three Anthology collections in 1995–96. The Fab Four managed seven consecutive No.1 albums in their homeland (1963–66). Their chart debut, Please Please Me (1963), remains the album to beat for most consecutive weeks at No.1 on UK albums chart (group, one album) – 30 weeks from 11 May to 30 November 1963. In both countries, The Beatles have the most cumulative weeks at No.1 (group, multiple albums) – 132 weeks in the USA and 174 weeks in the UK. Most UK chart singles by a songwriter McCartney has written or co-written 192 songs that have charted on the UK's Official Singles Chart since its launch in 1952. This total includes 32 hits with The Beatles, 21 with Wings and 36 as a soloist or as part of a duo or group. McCartney's 192nd and most recent chart entry was 'All Day', a collaboration with American rapper Kanye West that peaked at No.18 in 2015. And Paul is not through yet! He just had a #1 solo album in the top 200 albums in September 2018!

John. Because most of the Beatles’ songs are credited to both John and Paul, it’s hard to know who wrote what, but if you take into consideration the lead singer of each song, you almost know who wrote it. So, with that in mind, I’m going to try to narrow it down to who wrote the most. John Lennon sings lead on 73 [original] songs, which means he is, most likely, the sole songwriter.* Paul McCartney sings lead on 67 [original] songs, which means he is, most likely, the sole songwriter.** They both sing lead on 15 songs, which they actually wrote together. So, by the numbers, it’s clear that Lennon wrote the most songs, but Paul wrote more Number One hits (13*** to John’s 6) for the band. *John wrote I’m Happy Just to Dance with You to which George [Harrison] sings lead; and he wrote I Wanna Be Your Man to which Ringo sings lead (which means, he may have been the sole songwriter on 75 songs) **Paul wrote With a Little Help from My Friends and Yellow Submarine to which Ringo sings lead (which means, he may have been the sole songwriter on 68 songs) ***although, Ringo sings lead on Yellow Submarine (#1 in 1966), Paul is the sole songwriter

Early on many of the songs were a joint effort so I won’t include those songs as they were equally responsible for writing them. Of all the songs the Beatles recorded John had 72 songs where he was the main songwriter. Paul had 70 where he was the main songwriter. George wrote 22 songs and Ringo wrote 2. So by a narrow margin of 2 songs it was John since he wrote 72 to Paul’s 70. Basically they were pretty equal in their contributions in terms of number of songs anyway. For me at least it isn’t necessarily about numbers as much as it was about the quality of each song. Early on John wrote more hit songs than Paul did but that soon changed to where they were about equal and then Paul later on wrote more hits than John by quite a big margin. So I think it’s safe to say that Paul wrote more hit songs than John though John was not as concerned about the commerciality of the songs as much as Paul was. Both were fabulous songwriters and fair equal as afr was songwriting ability goes but it really comes down to personal preference and doesn’t really factor into this particular question.

There's no hard and fast answer, since there are so many factors to consider, in particular how you assign authorship to their collaborations, whether you count songs either wrote for other performers, and whether you restrict the answer to with the Beatles or lifetime output. Generally speaking, John and Paul contributed equally to 17 songs. John wrote 61 songs and Paul 43, with John dominating the Beatles' early years and Paul their later years. However, Paul wrote more #1 hits for the Beatles, 10, to John's 6. As a solo artist, John recorded 150 songs (though it's unclear how many were solo written and not with Yoko or someone else), and while I can't find an exact count for Paul his total appears to be somewhere north of 500. But the comparison is unfair since Paul has outlived John by 40 years, remaining creative the whole time.

Seeing the other answers , I think that you are underestimating Pauls’s backlog of songs . The ones that you talking about are songs that he has released . There are some mediocre and some fantastic songs that he has released under other names , (the Fireman) & allowed other artists to use and some that is available on on youtube as called Fab Trax volume 1 to 4 . There’s driving in the rain in the new century and many songs that he has allowed other artists to sing . So with John’s untimely death , there were a few songs that were only demo tapes but even taking that into account there are FAR more McCartney songs out there. For years John was during the dutiful Daddy job while Paul has been churning out songs non stop . ( an enormous amount of songs ) He even helped mis brother Mike ( mcGear- he didn’t want to trade off Pauls name ) & do some albums . I in 1974 Paul played and produced it . Then there was Badfinger, Mary Hopkins , Peter & Gordon and Billy J Kramer and quite a few other doing Pauls songs !

I read a book once that reviewed every Beatles song for authorship and it did a count, giving 1/2 to each when the song was (largely) written by both. As I recall John wrote a few more songs than Paul; less than 10 as I remember. It was very close. He also had about 1 more A side on the singles. Again, very close. But, I did a count of the Beatles number 1 songs and Paul had about 1 or 2 more of those than John. John tended to get the biggest piece of the pie in The Beatles because he started the group, he was older than all but Ringo, and he was also very talented and strong-willed. I remember this story about the white album. Paul had the idea to print small sequential numbers on the cover every white album (the old vinyl albums). Mine was about number 400,000. The 4 Beatles got numbers 1 through 4. Paul got number 2. Guess who got number 1?

Neil Sedaka. Er, I guess I was thinking of the Monkees. I remember my sister and I were kids and we couldn't figure out who was bigger, Herman's Hermits or the Beatles. Seriously, I think Lennon-McCartney were credited with about nine out of ten songs on the albums. A few they wrote together, more usually one acting as the quality control over the other. Towards the beginning, John wrote slightly more of the hits than Paul. Towards the end, Paul was dominant. As far as precise numbers, perhaps one of the more nerdy Quora people could break it down song by song. All in all, Lennon and McCartney were by no means equal, but the parity between them was amazingly equal.

Not a question that begs a straight answer for several reasons: Songs were dedicated to Lennon & McCartney regardless of which wrote them .Obviously Paul has written so many since John’s murder on 8th Dec 1980.There are many songs written by both including ‘A Day in the Life;’ ‘I Wanna Be Your Man’ (for the Rolling Stones); ‘I Want To Hold Your Hand’; ‘I Saw Her Standing There’; ‘With a Little Help from My Friends’ and ‘In My Life’As a general rule of thumb Paul leans to ballads like ‘Yesterday’ (though that could be argued against with John’s ‘Imagine’ and John’s tendency towards more rocky songs like ‘Baby You’re a Rich Man’ and ‘Help.’

Please, don’t believe in this fake story they were not really partners. They were. Lennon McCartney was real. What happened was that they didn’t live together, for they were very prolific. They used to start songs apart. But usually both would participate at least include a note or changing the beat or adding some words. By the way George and Ringo also woud colaborate in some. The introduction for And I love her is by George. And Paul create lots of sounds for Strawberry Fields Forever and also for Tomorrow Never knows. In fact, the psychodelic sound in both songs were Paul’s idea. The only thing we can say is which one had most of his first idea recorded. It was John’s. But, make no mistake, they were all The Beatles Eternal songs.

Paul McCartney wrote more songs by a long shot. But that was mostly after John Lennon was murdered. So my response isn’t really fair. If you mean while they were in The Beatles, John wrote more songs by a slim margin, due to the significantly larger amount he wrote in the band’s early years. Paul’s dominance as a songwriter came in the late 60’s and gradually caught up to John’s total, but never quite managed to exceed the amount that John had written.

William J. Dowlding in his book, Beatlesongs, attempts to break it down by examining each song, and referring whenever possible to material and information gleaned from various interviews and quotes - mostly from the group’s members. Mr. Dowlding - who I might add did a nice job in a book that is quite informative and fascinating - broke each song down to who contributed what, if anything, regardless of who was credited (I.e Lennon and McCartney). Here is what he came up with; these are the number of songs recorded and officially released by The Beatles written by various writers: Johe Lennon: 84.55 songs Paul McCartney: 73.65 songs George Harrison: 22.15 songs Ringo Starr: 2.7 songs The above counts total 183.05 songs. The other 25.95 songs were written or co-written by approximately 25 other different people. This totals - at the time of the book’s publication - 209 Beatle songs released (1989). Thanks!

In the long run McCartney. In total he has 180+ songs. Mostly because John died. As Beatles John had 61 to McCartneys 41. In the beginning John wrote the most ( he practically wrote a Hard Days Night soundtrack ). After Brian died John slowed down. He only had one song for Magical Mystery Tour. Sgt Pepper was mostly Paul.

I don’t think that this question should be asked on here. It’s obviously not fair to Lennon, because he has been dead now for 39 years. While McCartney is very much alive and has been able to write, record, and produce music. Then go on tour to promote and sell it. He has been doing this now for 49 almost 50 years since he left the Beatles. But, John’s life was cut short in 1980, just barely ten years after the band split. Of course the OP knows the answer, but is just looking for reassurance. Grow up is all I’ll give for an answer.

Absolutely yes…George and Ringo helped with some.. but Paul and John wrote hundreds of songs for the Beatles some have never been released The Beatles were geniuses behind the music written and composed by Paul and John..while the bubblegum music stopped for them… . A generation wanted something different.. they went on to write and sing rock and roll and they paved the way for so many..

Its hard to know exactly because there are songs written completely by the two of them together but that started to change in late 1963. Even between Lennon and McCartney, there is confusion as to who wrote what song or the majority of it. The general way to know who wrote a song mostly - go by who sang the lead vocal after 1964.

Lennon wrote 61 songs credited to ''Lennon-McCartney'' entirely by himself, and McCartney composed 43 on his own. All told, Lennon had a hand in composing 84.55 of the 209 songs recorded by the Beatles, and McCartney 73.65. George Harrison was a distant third, with 22.15 credits, and Ringo Starr fourth with 2.7.

As Beatles, it's likely very close to 50/50. John dominated until about 1967, after which Paul dominated. Now, if you include post-Beatles work, it's Paul by magnitudes, because it's hard to compose when you're dead. (And, no, I'm not going to make the obvious pun.)

Consensus seems to be that McCarthy was their primary writer, especially because he wrote “Yesterday”. However, many “experts” consider the song “Imagine”, written by Lennon, to be the best song of the Beatles era. People overlook, however, that George Harrison also contributed significantly to the Beatles’s rich music structures - including the writing of “Something” and “Here Comes the Sun”-

Here’s one way tell. If Paul is the singer, Paul was at least the originator. Same with John. They only really teamed up in the early years. You can also tell by the words & musical arrangement, at least most of the time. Johns “Julia” and “Why dont we do it in the Road” by Paul (all instruments too) are exceptions, as well as some others.

You can tell who wrote the songs most of the time when they would sing lead. After the break up and Johns absence, Paul composed so many songs that John wouldn’t be able to catch up with his famous partner. He would be pleased about his success .
Ackording to Ian MacDonald “Revolution In The Head” (page 12, second edition 2005) Lennon wrote about ten more songs than McCartney.

George was not in the big boy table while they were ‘The Beatles’, but he took a few notes and after the breakup he ruled. Everyone liked George, most liked Paul; you were asking about Yoko and Paul, George Martin and the crew
Yes
